Subject: Re: [junit] JUnit 4 issue: NaN handling
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=139771899; y=2JIZgPI6tPKQobpYn0Db8WlOMnjP880A36Jdo4EISzw
X-Yahoo-Profile: dsaff

This was discussed in the context of NUnit starting at:

http://groups.yahoo.com/group/testdrivendevelopment/message/11579

My biased summary:

1) The current behavior of JUnit, in which assertEquals(Double.NaN, x) 
always fails as unequal, is confusing and unhelpful.
2) Ron Jeffries favored special-casing NaN so that 
assertEquals(Double.NaN, Double.NaN, 0.1); passes.
3) I proposed having assertEquals(Double.NaN, x) always fail with a 
failure message ("Asserting equality with NaN is meaningless.  Please 
use assertIsNaN").

I think 2 or 3 is fine.

    David Saff

Elliotte Harold wrote:

> I think the handling of NaN by assertEquals(double, double, double) and
> assertEquals(float, float, float)  should be thought out and more
> carefully spelled out. For instance, the following assert fails:
>
>    assertEquals(Double.NaN, Double.NaN, 0.1);
>
> i.e. NaN is not equal to NaN. I'm honestly not sure whether this is
> correct or not. What does the principle of least surprise suggest? If
> someone understands NaN they may find this correct but someone who's not
> intimately familiar with NaN may be surprised.
>
> This edge case does have practical consequences. For one, the Apache
> Commons Math project has found it necessary to create their own double
> assertEquals methods that do consider NaN to be equal to NaN. See
>
> http://svn.apache.org/viewcvs.cgi/jakarta/commons/proper/math/trunk/src/test/org/apache/commons/math/TestUtils.java?rev=240245&view=markup 
> <http://svn.apache.org/viewcvs.cgi/jakarta/commons/proper/math/trunk/src/test/org/apache/commons/math/TestUtils.java?rev=240245&view=markup>
>
> I could go either way on this. However, I do think it's important that a
> definite decision about how to handle NaN be made, and that the result
> of this decision be spelled out in the JavaDoc. Currently Infinity is
> addressed but not NaN, and NaN is by far the more confusing case.
>
> It probably also wouldn't hurt to patch the JUnit 3 JavaDoc at least
> enough to document the current behavior, whatever that is.
>
> --
